newsitem.title: CHINA: HK govt sees no outright property speculation now.
newsitem.headline: HK govt sees no outright property speculation now.

text.p: Hong Kong Secretary for Housing Dominic Wong said on Friday that the territory's real estate market was currently dominated by end-users and he saw no current need to impose measures against property speculators.
But he told Reuters that the government continued to monitor the property market and did not rule out future action.
The government would make a "conscious decision" if speculation became rife, Wong said.
"A very, very high proportion of buyers are now end-users," he said in an interview.

Wong said the government's announcement last month that it would increase housing and land supply had helped cool escalating property prices. While the government was looking at possible measures to impose if speculation became rife, he said so far "the need is not indicated".
"The situation has not got to a point that we will do it but it does not mean that we will not do it," said Wong.
"Here I am dispelling some of the wrong statements that some people in the market seemed to have put out that the government are not doing anything. That is wrong."
Wong said while the government did not want to impose measures on speculators "unless absolutely necessary", it wanted speculators to stay out of the market.
"Although it has been our policy not to intervene in a free market, we do believe that to some extent housing is a necessity."
"We would not like to see the property market shooting all the way up so as to preclude people from purchasing their own properties," said Wong.
